spanishExample: ¡Di la manera de hacer esto!
englishTranslation: Say the manner of doing this!

spanishExample: ¿Adónde va ese niño?
englishTranslation: Where is that little kid (m) going?

spanishExample: Antes, ella había estado en su contra.
englishTranslation: Beforehand, she had been opposed to them.
vocabIncluded: había: "had", "he/she/it had" before a participle (Haber, imperfect, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Ayer quería decirle algo.
englishTranslation: Yesterday she wanted to tell him something.

spanishExample: Decía que ella está bajo *the table.*
englishTranslation: I was saying that she is under the table.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
decía: "was saying", "I was saying" (Decir, imperfect, 1st person)

spanishExample: Desde ya quieren que digamos eso, sea lo que sea.
englishTranslation: From now on they want us to say that, whatever it is.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
desde ya: "as of now", "from this moment on" (idiom)
sea lo que sea: "whatever it is" (idiom)

spanishExample: Dice que queremos hacer una pregunta.
englishTranslation: He says that we want to ask a question.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)

spanishExample: Dije que no quería hacer eso mientras él decía esas cosas.
englishTranslation: I said I didn’t want to do that while he was saying those things.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
decía: "was saying", "he/she/it was saying" (Decir, imperfect, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Dijeron que estuvo en una fiesta hace tres días, durante la semana.
englishTranslation: They said he was at a party three days ago, during the week.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)

spanishExample: Dijimos que estaba contra *the wall.*
englishTranslation: We said that she was against the wall.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)

spanishExample: Dijiste que esta gente ha estado aquí desde esta mañana.
englishTranslation: You said these people have been here since this morning.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
ha: "has", "he/she/it has" before a participle (Haber, present, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Dijo que fueron a la fiesta después.
englishTranslation: She said that they went to the party afterwards.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)

spanishExample: Dile que no va hacia el lugar.
englishTranslation: Tell him he is not going towards the place.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)

spanishExample: Dime si la niña no lo ha hecho aún.
englishTranslation: Tell me if the little girl hasn’t done it yet.
vocabIncluded: ha: "has", "he/she/it has" before a participle (Haber, present, 3rd person)

spanishExample: El bebé no ha dicho nada aún.
englishTranslation: The baby  (m) hasn’t said anything yet.
vocabIncluded: ha: "has", "he/she/it has" before a participle (Haber, present, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Ella quiere que yo le diga que tengo un poco de tiempo.
englishTranslation: She wants me to tell her that I have a little bit of time.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
le: "her/him" as an indirect object ("to her/him", "for her/him")

spanishExample: En ese caso, lo tendrían que hacer de vuelta.
englishTranslation: In that case, they would have to do it again.
vocabIncluded: tendrían: "would have", "they would have" (Tener, conditional, 3rd person plural)
using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

spanishExample: Es tarde, no quiero decir nada sobre eso.
englishTranslation: It’s late, I don’t want to say anything about that.

spanishExample: Ese es el lugar donde mi papá sleeps o sea, su lugar *favorite.*
englishTranslation: That’s the place where my dad sleeps, that is, his favorite place.

spanishExample: La oportunidad aún no es suya.
englishTranslation: The opportunity isn’t theirs yet.

spanishExample: La vuelta que *I gave* con mi esposo y mi hija fue buena.
englishTranslation: The walk I had with my husband and my daughter was nice.

spanishExample: Le decía eso a mi esposa de nuevo.
englishTranslation: I was telling that to my wife anew.
vocabIncluded: a, used in a "redundant indirect object", e.g. le hice un favor a la chica
decía: "was saying", "I was saying" (Decir, imperfect, 1st person)
le: "her/him" as an indirect object ("to her/him", "for her/him")

spanishExample: Mañana ese tipo va a estar ahí después de la fiesta.
englishTranslation: Tomorrow that dude is going to be there after the party.
vocabIncluded: a used after Volver to mean “again”
ahí: adverb meaning "there", especially when close to the speaker or listener

spanishExample: Mi hermano y yo dijimos que queremos a nuestra familia.
englishTranslation: My brother and I said that we love our family.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
"the personal a": using an extra "a" before a direct object when it's a person

spanishExample: No quiero que les digas eso, sobre todo a tu madre.
englishTranslation: I don’t want you to tell them that, especially to your mother.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
a, used in a "redundant indirect object", e.g. le hice un favor a la chica
les: "them" as an indirect object ("to them", "for them")

spanishExample: Que yo sepa, están diciendo la verdad.
englishTranslation: As far as I know, they are telling the truth.
vocabIncluded: que yo sepa: "as far as I know" (idiom)

spanishExample: Quiero decirte que no hay nada entre nosotros.
englishTranslation: I want to tell you that there isn’t anything between us.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
hay: "there is/are" indicating existence (Haber, present, impersonal)

spanishExample: Quiero que mi hermana me diga si van sin mi padre.
englishTranslation: I want my sister to tell me if they are going without my father.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
me: "me" as an indirect object ("to me", "for me")

spanishExample: Quiero que sepan que haré lo que quieran.
englishTranslation: I want them to know that I’ll do whatever they want.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
haré: "will do/make", "I will do/make" (Hacer, future, 1st person)

spanishExample: Quiero que sepas que ellos dicen la verdad.
englishTranslation: I want you to know that they are telling the truth.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)

spanishExample: Sabemos que *they are starting* desde ese lugar.
englishTranslation: We know they are starting from that place.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)

spanishExample: Si lo dices, puede que ellos también lo digan.
englishTranslation: If you say it, it might be that they also say it.

spanishExample: Si quisieran nuestra ayuda, lo dirían.
englishTranslation: If they wanted our help, they would say it.
vocabIncluded: dirían: "would say", "they would say" (Decir, conditional, 3rd person plural)
quisieran: "wanted", "they wanted" (Querer, past subjunctive, 3rd person plural)

spanishExample: Si quisieras ir, podrías ir luego.
englishTranslation: If you wanted to go, you could go later.
vocabIncluded: podrías: "would be able", "you would be able" (Poder, conditional, 2nd person)

spanishExample: Si supieras qué día es hoy, no sabrías qué decir.
englishTranslation: If you knew what day is today, you wouldn’t know what to say.
vocabIncluded: "qué" in an implied question, not an actual question
sabrías: "would know", "you would know" (Saber, conditional, 2nd person)

spanishExample: Sí, porque para entonces, estará aquí de vuelta.
englishTranslation: Yes, because by that time, she will be here again.
vocabIncluded: estará: "will be", "he/she/it will be" (Estar, future, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Siempre le decimos a nuestro hijo que esté en casa antes de las tres.
englishTranslation: We always tell our son to be home before 3.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
a, used in a "redundant indirect object", e.g. le hice un favor a la chica
le: "her/him" as an indirect object ("to her/him", "for her/him")

spanishExample: Te digo que lo sabré.
englishTranslation: I tell you that I will know it.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
sabré: "will know", "I will know" (Saber, future, 1st person)
te: "you" as an indirect object ("to you", "for you")

spanishExample: Te dirá que es tuyo.
englishTranslation: He will tell you that it’s yours(m).
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
dirá: "will say", "he/she/it will say" (Decir, future, 3rd person)
te: "you" as an indirect object ("to you", "for you")

spanishExample: Te diré el camino, pero tienes que saber que es mío.
englishTranslation: I’ll tell you the path, but you have to know that it’s mine.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
diré: "will say", "I will say" (Decir, future, 1st person)
te: "you" as an indirect object ("to you", "for you")
using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

spanishExample: Tienes que decirme eso, entonces lo sabré.
englishTranslation: You have to tell me that, then I’ll know it.
vocabIncluded: sabré: "will know", "I will know" (Saber, future, 1st person)
using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

spanishExample: Tienes que hacerle caso a tu mamá, entonces puedes ir.
englishTranslation: You have to obey your mom, then you can go.
vocabIncluded: using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation
